He further added that the other states were peaceful and hinted that the differences between the situation in the states show the who were encouraging violence.[\[490\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-490) On 23 December 2019, protests were held at multiple locations. 93 other students protesting outside Assam Bhawan and demanding the release of RTI activist Akhil Gogoi were detained by the police. The students alleged that the police used violence on the protesters.[\[491\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto5-491)[\[492\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-492) On 24 December 2019, Police imposed a ban on gatherings in central Delhi's [Mandi House](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandi_House) near the Lutyens' Zone to prevent the protest march of students from multiple universities. The anti CAA-NRC protest march was to start from Mandi House to [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar).[\[493\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-493)[\[494\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-494) On 27 December, the Delhi Police used [facial recognition software](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_recognition_software) by recording a video of the protester and checking it with the database of criminals maintained by them.[\[495\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Face_Recognition_28_Dec-495) On 14 January, [Supreme Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) lawyers conducted a protest march from the Supreme Court to Jantar Mantar to protest against the CAA, NRC and NPR.[\[496\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-496) On 19 January, in Delhi, hundreds of protesters joined a protest march holding lighted candles from Jamia University to Shaheen Bagh.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) Some of the protesters had dressed up as [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi), [BR Ambedkar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BR_Ambedkar) and other revolutionaries of the [Indian Independence movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Independence_movement). A model of detention camp was also paraded in the march.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) #### North East Delhi riots [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=21) Main article: [2020 Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Delhi_riots) Many Cars burnt by Mob in Shiv ViharThe burnt Gym at Shiv Vihar. On 24 February, [violent clashes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots) occurred at [Jaffrabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaffrabad,_Delhi) and Maujpur in which one police officer and a protester were killed. The pro-CAA demonstrators indulged in stone pelting with the anti-CAA protesters and vandalised houses, vehicles and shops. The police personnel used [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) and [lathicharge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lathicharge) against the protestors.[\[497\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-497)[\[498\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-498) Later, it was reported that four protestors also died during the violence.[\[340\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:4-340) The [Ministry of Home Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) stated that the violence appeared orchestrated because of U.S. President [Donald Trump](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump)'s visit to India.[\[499\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-499) On 26 February, The [United States Commission on International Religious Freedom](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Commission_on_International_Religious_Freedom) (USCIRF) condemned the violence in New Delhi.[\[500\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-500) USCIRF Chair [Tony Perkins](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Perkins_(politician)) said, "We urge the Indian government to make serious efforts to protect Muslims and others targeted by mob violence."[\[501\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-501) The Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) has also condemned the New Delhi violence. It stated that steps must be taken to prevent the incidents of " [Islamophobia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamophobia)" in the country. The OIC statement further went on to add that it "condemns the recent and alarming violence against Muslims in India, resulting in the death and injury of innocent people and the arson and vandalism of mosques and Muslim-owned properties."[\[502\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-502) The Government of India (GOI) has reacted by describing the criticism from the OIC as "inaccurate, selective, and misleading." The GOI also described USCIRF's criticism as "factually inaccurate and misleading, and appear to be aimed at politicising the issue." [\[503\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-503) #### Shaheen Bagh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=22) Main article: [Shaheen Bagh protest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protest) Shaheen Bagh on New Year's Eve. Since 14 December, a continuous 24/7 sit in protest is being conducted. The protest began in the afternoon of 14 December with just 15 local women, and went on to gather thousands of protesters with crowds reaching as high as 100,000 on Sundays.[\[504\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-504)[\[505\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-505) On New Year's Eve, thousands of protesters camping at the site sung the [Indian national anthem](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_anthem).[\[506\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-506) They were joined in by celebrities and activists on 31 December.[\[507\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-507) But in a turn of events, the protest took a turn for the worst when anti India slogans were shouted at Shaheen Bagh with reference to Jinnah and a call out to try and break India ( _Jinnah wali Azadi_), where many miscreants with their own agenda had joined.[\[508\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-508) The day was also recorded to have been the coldest in Delhi in the past 100 years.[\[509\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-509) On 10 January, the [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) rejected a plea to shift the Shaheen Bagh protesters.[\[510\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-510) The area has been covered with protest artwork.[\[511\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-511) ### West Bengal [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=23) On Saturday, 14 December 2019, violent protests occurred in West Bengal as the protesters attacked railway stations and public buses. Five trains were set on fire by the protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district); railway tracks were also damaged in Suti.[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) On Monday, 16 December 2019, tens of thousands of people joined a protest march led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) Mamata Banerjee stated that the NRC and CAA would not be implemented in West Bengal state as long as she was alive. She appealed people not to resort to violence, while accusing people from outside the state and members of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) of engaging in arson.[\[512\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-512)[\[513\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-513) On Tuesday, 17 December 2019, protests that included road and rail blockades continued in parts of West Bengal including the districts of [South 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_24_Parganas), [North 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_24_Parganas_district) and [Nadia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadia_district).[\[514\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-514) On 19 December 2019, a crowd with thousands of protesters gathered at Moulali in central Kolkata to peacefully object CAA and NRC.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) Mamata Banerjee held a second rally in Kolkata and stated that the Central Government was trying to project the CAA Protests as though it was a Hindu vs Muslim fight.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) She also stated that "BJP is buying skull caps for its cadres who are wearing them while vandalising properties to malign a particular community,".[\[515\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Kolkata_Rally-515) Earlier, on 18 December, a young [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) worker along with five associates, wearing [lungi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lungi) and [skullcap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taqiyah_(cap)) were seen by the local residents throwing stones on a train engine. The arsonists were caught by the locals who handed them to the [Murshidabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad) police.[\[516\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-516)[\[517\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-517)[\[518\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-518) On 21 December 2019, a protest march that the police estimated to be of 10,000 people was held in [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) from [Shahid Minar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Kolkata) till [Mahajati Sadan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahajati_Sadan).[\[185\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TelegraphFloodgates-185) Between 13 and 17 December 2019, multiple incidents of violence were reported during the protests. According to the police, as of 21 December, more than 600 people had been arrested for allegedly being involved in the violence.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 23 December 2019, Governor [Jagdeep Dhankhar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jagdeep_Dhankhar) was stopped by the students at [Jadavpur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadavpur_University), from attending the university convocation ceremony. The vice-president of the BJP West Bengal unit raised questions that why the Muslims were excluded from the amendment if it was not about religion.[\[519\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-519) On 24 December 2019, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee lead a protest march in Kolkata from [Swami Vivekananda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda) statue at [Bidhan Sarani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidhan_Sarani). She accused PM Narendra Modi and Union Home Minister Amit Shah of making contradictory statements. She stated "The prime minister is saying there has been no discussion or proposal on NRC. But a few days ago, BJP president and Union Home Minister Amit Shah had said NRC exercise would be carried out across the country. Both the statements are contradictory. We wonder who is speaking the truth. They are trying to create confusion,".[\[520\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-520) On 3 January, the radical Islamic organisation [Popular Front of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Front_of_India) (PFI) had planned an anti CAA protest for 5 January, but the West Bengal police denied permission for it.[\[521\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_PFI_3_Jan-521) Since 7 January, women had been conducting a sit in protest at the grounds of Park Circus in Kolkata.[\[239\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Park_Circus_16_Jan-239) On 11 January, PM Modi visited Kolkata on a two-day official visit. Hundreds of people protested against CAA at the Kolkata airport.[\[247\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rediff_11_Jan-247) Several parties and student unions launched a protest at the Dorina Crossing at Esplanade in Kolkata. SFI leader stated that the protests would continue till Sunday, until PM Modi (who had been visiting the city) was in Kolkata.[\[248\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_11_Jan-248) On 22 January, a 5 kilometre long procession against CAA was led by CM Mamta Bannerjee in [Darjeeling](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darjeeling), West Bengal. The participants wore ethnic dresses and also played musical instruments. The participants chanted anti CAA slogans and carried banners and posters.[\[287\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Darjeeling-287) On 26 January (Republic Day), thousands formed parallel 11 km long human chains from [Shyambazar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shyambazar) to Golpark in Kolkata.[\[522\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-522) ### Punjab [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=24) Protests begun in [Malerkotta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malerkotla), [Patiala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patiala) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana) with the support of [Khalsa Aid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khalsa_Aid), Alliance of Sikh Organisations and various Dalit organisations.[\[523\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-523) By 17 December, protests were being held in [Amritsar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amritsar), Malerkotla, [Machhiwara](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machhiwara), [Bathinda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bathinda) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana). Students of [Panjab University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjab_University), [Punjabi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjabi_University) and [Central University of Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_University_of_Punjab) took a leading role in the protests backed by the Association of Democratic Rights. [Razia Sultana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Razia_Sultana_(politician)), the only Muslim MLA and a Minister of the [Punjab Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Amarinder_Singh_ministry) organised a large protest in Malerkotla.[\[524\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-524) A cabinet meeting in Punjab decided to proceed as per the decision of the state assembly. A statement was released stating, "The ministers also expressed concern over the implications of the blatantly unconstitutional and divisive CAA, NRC and NPR," They also expressed concern on the violence over CAA stating, the issue "threatened to rip apart the secular fabric of the nation".[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) ### Uttar Pradesh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=25) Main article: [CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAA_protests_in_Uttar_Pradesh) Protests were held in [Aligarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh), [Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur), [Bareilly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bareilly), [Varanasi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varanasi) and [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow).[\[525\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-525) [Banaras Hindu University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University) students also protested the police action targeting AMU and Jamia students.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) However, they also held a rally in support of the CAA and NRC.[\[527\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-527) On 19 December, the administration banned public assembly all over the state to prevent further protests in the state. Access to the internet was restricted in [Azamgarh district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azamgarh_district) for 2 days, after protest continued for 2 days in the area.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) In Lucknow, several buses, cars, media vans and motorbikes were torched. [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh) Chief Minister [Yogi Adityanath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath) stated that the authorities would seize the properties of those who indulge in violence in the state.[\[528\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-528) On 20 December 2019, six protesters are killed in police firing in UP.[\[180\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_6_deaths_in_up-180) According to the [Press Trust of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_Trust_of_India), the death toll from Friday's protests in Uttar Pradesh's 13 districts has risen to 11.[\[69\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-al_jazeera-69) On 21 December 2019, violent protests along with alleged police brutality were reported from several districts across the state. Access to the internet was restricted. The number of fatalities in the state increased to 16.[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) Multiple clashes causing injuries to several people were reported. According to the police, 263 policemen were injured, of which 57 were firearm injuries. NDTV later reported that they could only find one policeman with bullet wound and the police did not share the list of 57 policemen with bullet injuries.[\[529\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_4_Jan_bullet-529) Police arrested 705 people in the state, with 102 arrested for making allegedly objectionable remarks or social media posts.[\[530\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-530)[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) According to the UP Police, as of 21 December, a total of 218 people had been arrested in Lucknow.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 24 December, [Uttar Pradesh Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh_Police) stated that 21,500 people were charged in 15 FIRs for violent incidents in Kanpur.[\[531\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-531) In [Muzaffarnagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muzaffarnagar) the government, sealed 67 shops. Chief Minister, Adityanath had threatened the protesters that his government would auction the properties of the rioters to recover the losses due to the damage made to the property.[\[200\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Muzaffarnagar-200)[\[201\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SiasatRakshak-201)[\[532\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-532)[\[202\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTVVandalising-202) On 26 December, In Sambhal, UP, the government sent notices to 26 people for their alleged involvement in damaging properties during protests and asked them to explain their position or pay for the loss due to damage of property. The losses to the property were assessed to be [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)11.66 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$14,000).[\[204\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sambhal_Damage-204) Earlier, on 22 December, the UP government had created a panel to assess the damage to the property and to recover the losses by seizing the property of the alleged protesters.[\[191\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Lucknow_22_Dec_IT-191) The social activists accused the government of intimidating the protesters.[\[533\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-533) On 28 December, the _Indian Express_ reported that with 19 killed and 1,246 people arrested based on 372 FIRs lodged in the state, UP was the worst affected state with the biggest police crackdown in India.[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Even though the official figure of number of deaths so far in UP was 19, opposition parties claimed that the actual figure was higher. The UP police had maintained that the deaths of protesters were not the result of police firing, but later on they admitted that some deaths were indeed caused by the police but attributed those incidents to shots fired in self defence.[\[534\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Deaths_5_Jan-534) On 17 January in Lucknow, around 500 women along with their children started a sit in protest at 2 pm near the Clock Tower.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270)(subscription required)[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police tried to convince them to end the protest but the protesters refused to move. On the night of 18 January, Uttar Pradesh police cracked down on the CAA protesters and snatched their blankets, utensils and food items.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The video of policemen carrying away the blankets was recorded and shared on social media. The conduct of UP police was criticised by the users and the phrase "KAMBALCHOR\_UPPOLICE" (blanket thief UP Police) became the top trend on Twitter in India.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The police responded saying that they had confiscated the blankets following due procedure. The protesters alleged that police also cut the electricity connection to the ground, locked the public toilet nearby and poured water on the bonfire in the winter night.[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police had issued a prohibition on assembly in Lucknow,[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) and stated that they will prosecute the protesters for violating it.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270) On 21 January, police registered cases against 160 women for violation of the ban on assembly and protesting against CAA in Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) On 16 December, in response to the police crackdown at Jamia Millia University in Delhi and Aligarh Muslim University over the Citizenship Amendment Act, clashes between the police and protesters occurred in Dakshintola area of [Mau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mau,_Uttar_Pradesh), Uttar Pradesh. On 17 December, students of [IIT Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Kanpur) assembled in a peaceful protest against the CAA and to express solidarity with the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia).[\[536\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-536) ### Karnataka [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=26) On 16 December, protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were held in various parts of [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka). In [Mysore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mysore), hundreds of protestors marched on the street, raising slogans and took out bike rallies. Chandrashekar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._Chandrashekar_Rao), whose party [Telangana Rashtra Samithi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Rashtra_Samithi) had voted against the bill in parliament, to end his silence with respect to the CAA.[\[580\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-580) By 23 December, it was reported that protests had spread to smaller towns, including Nizamabad.[\[581\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-581) On 4 January, more than 100,000 protesters attended the protest march named "Million March" in Hyderabad.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) The protesters displayed placards with slogans saying "Withdraw CAA immediately," and "India's only religion in secularism".[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) ### Bihar [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=33) On 17 December, posters describing Bihar Chief Minister [Nitish Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitish_Kumar) as "missing" were erected as a form of protest in Patna. Nitish Kumar had been criticised for his silence over the CAA. while his party, [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)), had supported the bill in both the Houses of Parliament as part of the alliance with the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party). The JD(U) party strategist [Prashant Kishor](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prashant_Kishor), party spokesperson [Pavan Verma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavan_Varma) and MLC [Gulam Rasool Balyawi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulam_Rasool_Balyawi) had voiced dissatisfaction over the party's stance on CAA.[\[582\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-582)[\[583\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-583) On 19 December, Nitish Kumar declared that the NRC will not be implemented in the state, becoming the first major [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) ally to reject the controversial measure.[\[584\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-584) On 19 December, a [bandh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandh) was called by [communist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism) parties in [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), supported by a number of small parties, where protesters blocked rail and road traffic in protest against CAA and the proposed countrywide implementation of NRC.[\[585\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-585)[\[425\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HBL-425) On Saturday, 21 December, a "Bihar bandh" was called by the [Rashtriya Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal) (RJD), where bandh supporters reportedly blocked railway tracks in [Araria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Araria_district) and [East Champaran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Champaran_district) districts. In [Nawada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nawada), bandh supporters demonstrated on [National Highway 31](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Highway_31_(India)) where wheels were burned on the road and the movement of vehicles was disrupted, while in [Vaishali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaishali_district), the highway was blocked with the help of buffaloes. In Patna, hundreds of party supporters with lathis entered the railway stations and bus stations with party flags, but were repulsed by policemen. At [Darbhanga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darbhanga), RJD workers and supporters protested bare chest, sloganeering against Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar and central government.[\[586\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-586)[\[587\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-587) During a protest at [Phulwari Sharif](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phulwari_Sharif) near Patna, some of the miscreants started pelting stones and a clash broke out between protesters and the supporters of the Act. A nearby temple and a cemetery were damaged in the clash. Eyewitnesses said police had used tear gas and water cannon to disperse the people. Police said that people of Hindu community fired bullets that injured nine Muslim men.[\[588\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-588) During the stampede, an eighteen years old teenage protester Amir Hanzla ran towards the lanes of Sangat Mohalla, a neighbourhood that was a hub of [RSS-affiliated](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS-affiliated) right wing Hindutva members.[\[589\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-589) His dead body was found a week after he was allegedly murdered by the [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) extremists.[\[590\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-590) Police arrested six people accused in the case who belonged to Hindu Putra Sangathan, a Hindutva group. All of the suspects confessed their crimes and police is also investigating 18 other organisations related to this extremist In the rally a high court judge, Ravi Shakar Bhure said that the judiciary had become helpless as well and termed the actions of the government to be part of a massive conspiracy.[\[602\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-602) ### Northeast India [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=37) The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) implementation has faced significant opposition in Northeast India, especially in Assam. Critics argue the CAA is discriminatory and undermines indigenous rights . The central government's decision to exclude most tribal areas from the CAA has been met with mixed reactions, as regions like Assam still largely fall outside the Sixth Schedule and are thus not exempted .[\[603\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-603) Assam, due to its porous borders with Bangladesh, has been particularly affected by illegal immigration, which heightens the controversy surrounding the CAA . Existing student bodies, such as the Northeast Student Union (NESU), have been criticized for their inaction on the issue . In response, the Wesean Student Federation (WSF) was formed in March 2024, advocating for international intervention and urging the United Nations to address the CAA's discriminatory aspects .[\[604\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-604)[\[605\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-605) Calls for excluding the entire Northeast from the CAA's purview have been persistent, reflecting widespread regional discontent . In Assam, only areas under the Sixth Schedule, like the Bodoland Territorial Region, are exempt, leaving much of the state vulnerable to the CAA . This discrepancy has sparked questions about the state's policy consistency, as highlighted by All Assam Students Union Chief Advisor Samujjal Bhattacharya .[\[606\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-606) Efforts to grant Scheduled Tribe status to additional Assamese communities could potentially lead to a tribal-majority state fully exempt from the CAA, though this has not yet materialized . Meanwhile, organizations like the Asom Jatiyatabadi Yuba Chatra Parishad (AJYCP) are pushing for the implementation of an [Inner Line Permit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inner_Line_Permit) system to further protect against illegal immigration .[\[607\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-607) ### Other states and union territories [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=38) - **Meghalaya:** On 9 December, large scale protests were held in the state. ## Participants [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=43) The law was considered controversial since the time it was proposed, leading to protests from students, political organisations and citizen groups. On 4 December, the draft legislation was shared and the student organisation, [All Assam Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) (AASU) objected to the proposal. AASU had participated in the [Assam Movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Movement) in the 1970s and 1980s against the illegal immigration of Bangladeshis.[\[677\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-MC_short_history-677) The protests started in Assam in early December. By 12 December, students in at least 50 colleges and universities nationwide had joined the protests.[\[678\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-678) The student protests subsequently grew and spread all over the country and several political and citizen groups joined it.[\[677\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-MC_short_history-677) The protests came into national and international prominence after the police crackdown following the violent crackdown of protests in Aligarh Muslim University[\[679\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-679)[\[680\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-680) and Jamia Millia Islamia.[\[681\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-681)[\[682\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-682) Student leaders from Jamia Millia Islamia Aysha Renna[\[683\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-683) and Ladeeda Farzana who were brutally attacked became the prominent faces of the movement.[\[684\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-684)[\[685\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-685)[\[686\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-686)[\[687\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-687)[\[688\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-688) ### Student organisations [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=44) #### Protesting [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=45) - In an interview to _[The Hindu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hindu)_, he said, "We don't have persecuted minorities in Afghanistan." Mentioning about the [Afghanistan conflict](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan_conflict_(1978%E2%80%93present)), he said, "The whole country is persecuted. We have been in war and conflict for a long time. All religions in Afghanistan, Muslims and Hindus and Sikhs, which are our three main religions, have suffered."[\[754\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-754) - **Bangladesh**: In an interview to _[Gulf News](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_News)_ Bangladesh Prime Minister [Sheikh Hasina](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina) said, "Within India, people are facing many problems" and expressed her concerns saying, "We don't understand why (the Indian government) did it. It was not necessary". Though she maintained her stance that the CAA and NRC are internal matters of India. But Hasina's government had previously said that minority communities did not leave Bangladesh because of persecution. She also said that Prime Minister Modi assured her of no reverse migration from India.[\[755\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-755) - **China**: _[People's Daily](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Daily)_, an official newspaper of [Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party), justified internet restrictions citing India's internet shutdowns. The newspaper said that India did not hesitate to shut down the internet in its two states when there was a significant threat to its national security; according to an article in _[The Times of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Times_of_India)_, activists described the justification as setting a dangerous precedent for internet freedom.[\[756\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-756)[\[757\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-757) - **Hungary**: The [Fidesz](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fidesz) Hungarian government in Hungary has expressed support for India on [Kashmir](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revocation_of_the_special_status_of_Jammu_and_Kashmir) and the Citizenship Amendment Act protests.[\[758\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-758) - **Kuwait**: In a statement issued during [National Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_(Kuwait)) session in Kuwait group of lawmakers expressed their concern regarding "abusive legislative and repressive security measures" taken by the Government of India.[\[759\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-759) - **Malaysia**: Malaysian Prime Minister [Mahathir Mohamad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahathir_Mohamad) said "Already people are dying because of this law, so why is there a necessity to do this thing?".[\[760\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-760) In response, the Government of India summoned the Chargé d'Affaires of the Malaysian Embassy over the matter.[\[761\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-761) - **Pakistan**: The Prime Minister of Pakistan, [Imran Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imran_Khan) criticised the CAA by claiming that "the present Government. of India has been exposed of its fascist agenda as minorities have come out to protest against the CAA". He also expressed his concern that, such policies by the government. may create a major refugee crisis in the sub-continent.[\[762\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-762)[\[763\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-763) - **United States**: [US Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress) think tank [Congressional Research Service](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_Research_Service) expressed concerns that the CAA along with the NRC may affect the status of the Indian Muslim community.[\[764\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-764) #### Organisation [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=57) - **European Union**: EU resolution states that CAA marks 'a dangerous shift ' in the way citizenship will be determined in India and is set to create the 'largest statelessness crisis in the world'.[\[765\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-765) - **Organisation of Islamic Cooperation**: [OIC](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation) expressed their concern about present situation of CAA-NRC and urged the Government of India to ensure the safety of the Muslim minority and to follow obligation of [Charter of the United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charter_of_the_United_Nations).[\[766\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-766) - **United Nations**: [Secretary-General of the United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations), [António Guterres](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres) condemned the "violence and alleged use of excessive force by security forces" and urged the Government of India to respect the freedom of expression and opinion and [freedom of peaceful assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly).[\[767\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-767) ### Human rights organisations [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=58) - [United Nations Commission on Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Commission_on_Human_Rights) (UNCHR): [Stéphane Dujarric](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Dujarric), the spokesperson for the [U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) (OHCHR) had said that it is ‘concerned’ that the CAA is ‘fundamentally discriminatory in nature’.[\[768\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-768) In a press briefing OHCHR said that CAA appears to "undermine the commitment to equality before the law enshrined in India's constitution and India's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination", which prohibit discrimination based on racial, ethnic or religious grounds. It also said that "all migrants, regardless of their migration status, are entitled to respect, protection and fulfilment of their human rights."[\[769\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-769) - [Human Rights Watch](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch) (HRW): South Asia Director for HRW, Meenakshi Ganguly said that the "government failed to grasp the extent of public opposition over the erosion of basic rights evident in these protests". She urged that the government must establish an independent investigation into allegations of "excessive force, brutality, and vandalism" by police. Its "strongest response to the protests would be to repeal" the Act and "withdraw its plan for citizenship verification that threatens marginalized communities", the organisation said.[\[770\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-770) According to an 82-page report published on 9 April 2020, by [Human Rights Watch](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch), "‘Shoot the Traitors’: Discrimination Against Muslims Under India's New Citizenship Policy," the police forces and other law enforcement officials perpetually failed in intervening during clashes between the supporters of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) government and those protesting against the new citizenship policies, in which the latter became a victim of repeated attacks.[\[771\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-771) - [Amnesty International](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International): Avinash Kumar, Executive Director of Amnesty India said "The CAA is a bigoted law that legitimises discrimination on the basis of religion." He also said that people should have the right to protest peacefully and should have right to freedom of peaceful assembly which facilitate freedom of expression and allows public debate. However, the Central Government and other state governments "rather than respecting, protecting and promoting this right, are clamping down on protestors by using repressive laws".[\[772\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-772) Amnesty has also informed the US lawmakers that the CAA stands in "clear violation" of the constitution of India and international human rights law and "legitimises discrimination" on the basis of Netflix called the offer as fake.[\[807\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Netflix_4_Jan-807) ### Fake videos [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=65) A video of _[Naga Sadhus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naga_Sadhu)_ celebrating at [Kumbh Mela](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumbh_Mela) at [Allahabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allahabad) in March 2019 was shared and made [viral](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_video) on social media,[\[808\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-808) falsely claiming that this was the video of Hindus in the rally supporting CAA.[\[809\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DB_8_Jan_fake_video-809)[\[810\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-810) ### Overseas [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=66) Members of the Indian-American community held a pro-CAA rally in front of the Indian Consulate in Houston on 20 December 2019.[\[811\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-811) They also held other rallies at [Victor Steinbrueck Park](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck_Park), [Seattle](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle) and [Texas State Capitol](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_State_Capitol) building in [Austin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin,_Texas) on 22 December 2019. Rallies were also held at Ted Kaltenbach Park, [Dublin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin,_California), [Ohio](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio) and at Nash Square Park, [Raleigh, North Carolina](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raleigh,_North_Carolina).[\[812\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-812) ## Petitions in Supreme Court [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=67) On 14 January, the [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under section 131 of the constitution that provides Supreme Court the power to decide the disputes between the states and the Government of India.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) The Kerala government in its petition called the act "a violation of India's secular constitution" and accused the Indian government of dividing the country among religious lines.[\[577\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_14_Jan-577) The Supreme Court had scheduled the hearing of CAA related petitions on 22 January. The students' association have called a complete shutdown of the colleges and university in the north-east, on 22 January, asking the court to declare CAA unconstitutional.[\[283\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_NE_strike_21_Jan-283) On 22 January 144 CAA related petitions scheduled for hearing in the Supreme Court of India were brought up. The [Chief Justice of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India) (CJI) [Sharad A. Bobde](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharad_A._Bobde) had led the three judge bench in hearing the petitions.[\[289\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-144_petitions_21_Jan-289) The court gave notice to the government on the petitions and allowed one month time to respond in the next hearing in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) K.V. Vishwanathan, a senior advocate addressed the court, stating "The most immediate concern now is the sweeping powers given to [executive authorities](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government)) to brand people as 'doubtful citizens'. Once this is done, there are no guidelines to help these people. This is sinister. It will lead to [gerrymandering](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerrymandering) of electoral rolls. The concern is spread across both the majority Hindus and the minorities as well. You have to address this fear... Otherwise fear and insecurity will pervade the country."[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) Reacting to the concerns the CJI stated that the laws like the CAA are not irreversible, and the court will hear the interim prayer for a stay on CAA at a future date in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) On 3 March, the [Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) (OHCHR), filed an application in the Supreme Court and asked to be made a party in the case citing "the exclusions of persons... on the basis of their religion". The OHCHR Commissioner, [Michelle Bachelet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelle_Bachelet) said that the "differentiations" drawn by the Act are not "sufficiently objective and reasonable". However, the [Ministry of External Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_External_Affairs_(India)) reacted to the move and said that the CAA is an "internal matter" of India and "no foreign party had any locus standi on issues pertaining to India's sovereignty".[\[813\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-813)[\[348\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UN_moves_to_SC-348) ## See also [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=68) -
